Front: What is machine learning?
Back: Algorithms that learn patterns from data

Front: What are the three main types of machine learning?
What does supervised learning use?
What does unsupervised learning work with?
What does reinforcement learning maximize?
Machine learning evolved as a subfield of {{c1::artificial intelligence (AI)}}
Why use ML over manual rules?
Back: ML captures patterns automatically from data

Front: What does "labeled data" mean?
Back: Data where each example has a known output/answer

Front: What is a "model" in ML?
Back: A learned function that maps inputs to outputs

Front: What is "training" in ML?
Back: The process of learning model parameters from data

Front: Why is supervised learning called "supervised"?
What is the goal of supervised learning?
Back: Predict outputs for new, unseen data

Front: What are the two types of supervised learning?
What does classification predict?
What does regression predict?
What is binary classification?
Give an example of binary classification.
What is a decision boundary?
What is multiclass classification?
Back: Predicting one of more than two classes

Front: Give an example of multiclass classification.
What are predictor variables also called?
What are response variables also called?
What is reinforcement learning?
What is an "agent" in RL?
Back: The system that learns and takes actions

Front: What is the "environment" in RL?
What is a "reward signal"?
Back: Feedback indicating how good an action was

Front: How does an RL agent learn?
Give an example of reinforcement learning.
What is unsupervised learning?
Back: Finding hidden structure in unlabeled data

Front: What is clustering?
Why is clustering called "unsupervised classification"?
Back: It groups data without predefined labels

Front: Give an application of clustering.
What is dimensionality reduction?
Back: Reducing number of features while preserving information

Front: Name two benefits of dimensionality reduction.
How can dimensionality reduction improve models?
Back: By removing noise from irrelevant features

A {{c1::feature}} is one column in a dataset

What is a cost function?

Subscript {{c1::j}} refers to the jth feature

Why is preprocessing crucial?
Back: Raw data is rarely optimal for algorithms

Front: What is feature scaling?
Feature scaling often uses range {{c1::[0, 1]}} or standard normal
What is standard normal distribution?
Why split data into training and test sets?
Back: To check if model generalizes to new data

Front: When should test data be used?
What is the "No Free Lunch" theorem?
Back: No single algorithm is best for all tasks

Front: What does No Free Lunch imply?
What is classification accuracy?
What is cross-validation?
What are hyperparameters?
Back: Model settings not learned from data

Front: Give examples of hyperparameters.
What is generalization error?
Why fit preprocessing only on training data?
Back: To avoid information leakage from test set
